trial_identification.studytitle: Protease supplementation and delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS)
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised placebo controlled crossover trial to compare the effects of consumption of a protease supplement on delayed muscle soreness in healthy males.

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal musculoskeletal and cartilage development and function

interventions.interventions: This will be a randomised, placebo-controlled, crossover study with two arms. Arm 1: Whey protein drink (500mL) with a protease enzyme (43mg). Arm 2: Whey protein drink (500mL) without the protease enzyme. This study will be carried out to assess the effects of consuming a whey protein drink with and without a protease on delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS), physical performance, inflammation, and amino acid availability. Participants will be assigned in random order to receive the 2 treatments. There will be a 4-week washout between treatments. The beverages will be consumed for 4 days before exercise and 4 days following exercise. On the exercise day the beverage will be consumed immediately following exercise. For the exercise component each participant will complete a 30 min downhill run on a treadmill with a -10% grade at 70% their maximal heartrate.
interventions.comparator: Placebo: Will receive the whey protein beverage without the protease.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary Outcome 1: Perceived muscle soreness using a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) and an algometer.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: at baseline, and 3, 24, 48, 72 and 96 hours post-exercise

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary Outcome 2: Muscle strength using a Biosex Isokinetic Dynanometer.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: at baseline and 3 days post-exercise

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary Outcome 3: Inflammation Plasma assay for CRP
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: at baseline, and 24, 48 and 72 hours post-exercise

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Secondary Outcome 1: blood amino acid concentration
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: at baseline, and 15, 30, 45, 60, 75, 90 and 120 minutes post-ingestion of whey protein with and without the protease.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Healthy, physically active males aged between 18 and 40 years.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: People with chronic disease People who are unable to run continuously for 45 minutes People with dairy allergies People with lactose intolerance People with dairy intolerance

trial_design.concealment: Allocation concealment will be used. This will be achieved through allocation being performed by a research assistant who will have no involvement in the enrolment process.
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation will be performed using a randomisation table created by computer software.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: University of Otago PO Box 56 Dunedin, 9054 New Zealand

fundingsource.fundingaddress: 1013 Centre Rd Suite 106 Wilmington, DE 19805 USA

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Eccentric exercise such as down hill running can cause muscle damage and soreness, which typically peaks after 2-4 days. This is referred to as delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS). Supplementation with proteases (a group of biologically active enzymes) may reduce this damage, possibly by reducing inflammation. This project will compare the effects of a protease supplement versus a placebo on delayed muscle soreness, physical performance and inflammation following a bout of eccentric exercise. A secondary aim of this project is to assess the uptake of amino acids from a whey protein supplement with and without (placebo) the addition of a protease.
